tourName: North East India tailor made holiday
generalInfo:
Discover India’s most remote and intriguing region, where unique tribal cultures, wildlife sanctuaries, and sprawling tea gardens await. This carefully crafted itinerary highlights the very best of North East India – from vibrant local traditions and rare wildlife to mighty rivers and some of the world’s finest tea. Begin in Meghalaya, the “Scotland of the East,” and immerse yourself in its matrilineal society.
A highlight of the trip is the visit to the Kaziranga National Park to spot tigers and the iconic one-horned rhino. You will also explore Majuli, the world’s largest river island, and encounter the fierce, tattooed headhunting tribes along the Burmese border. Finally, unwind with a truly authentic Assam tea experience in a heritage planter’s bungalow in Dibrugarh.

dayInfo.description: Welcome to India - Upon arriving in Kolkata, you will be met and transferred to your hotel. Relax and put your feet up to prepare for the adventure ahead.

Kolkata - Kolkata is a city full of character and contrasts, best explored with the insight of a private guide. Start with some of its most iconic landmarks, such as the grand Victoria Memorial and gallery, the peaceful Botanical Gardens, and Mother Teresa’s Missionaries of Charity. In the afternoon, join a “confluence of cultures” walking tour to discover the many global communities who have shaped the city over the centuries – from the Chinese, Parsis and Armenians to Anglo-Indians and people from across India. Round off the day with a serene evening cruise along the Hooghly, a tributary of the sacred Ganges.

Shillong - This morning, we’ll collect you from your hotel and transfer you to the airport for the one-hour flight to Guwahati. From here, a scenic three-hour drive winds uphill to Shillong, the charming hill station and capital of Meghalaya. On arrival, check in to your hotel – Tripura Castle, once the summer residence of the Maharaja of Tripura – before heading out to explore Bara Bazaar, the bustling outdoor “big market”.

Around Shillong - The Khasi people follow a matrilineal system, a striking contrast to the strongly patriarchal traditions found in much of India. Today, your guide will take you beyond Shillong into rural villages to meet members of the Khasi community, with a special stop in Smit – the traditional seat of Khasi royalty and culture. Here, you might see timber houses with sloping tin roofs, women in distinctive 'jainsem' dress, and open spaces where community gatherings and festivals take place.

Living Root Bridges at Laitkynsew - One of the most remarkable features of this region are the living root bridges, created by guiding and intertwining the aerial roots of rubber trees to form natural crossings over rivers. They take decades to grow strong enough to use, so communities here rely on bridges built by their ancestors while nurturing new ones for generations yet to come. From Shillong, it’s a scenic 1.5-hour drive each way through the hills to Laitkynsew to see these extraordinary structures, with the option to stop at Cherrapunjee to admire its dramatic waterfalls.

Kaziranga National Park - Today’s journey to Kaziranga in Assam takes around six hours along good roads. As you near the park, keep an eye out – you may be lucky enough to spot one of the area’s iconic one-horned rhinos grazing in the distance. On arrival, check in to your resort and take the rest of the day to relax.

Kaziranga National Park - Today, you’ll venture into Kaziranga National Park on two game drives – one at first light, the other in the late afternoon glow – travelling in open-top jeeps with your expert naturalist guide. The early mist adds a touch of magic, drifting over the wide, open landscapes of elephant grass. This is the only place in the world where you can see the endangered one-horned rhinoceros in the wild, alongside wild boar, water buffalo and a wealth of birdlife. And if luck is on your side, you might just catch a fleeting glimpse of a tiger.

Majuli Island - This morning, you’ll be driven for a couple of hours to board the public ferry to Majuli Island, still within Assam. The 1.5-hour crossing is an experience in itself, shared with local passengers and sometimes their livestock, offering a glimpse of daily life along the Brahmaputra. Majuli is the world’s largest river island, though sadly it is shrinking fast and may not survive many more decades. Homes here are built on stilts to protect against flooding and wandering wildlife, and tonight you’ll stay in a traditional house. During your visit, you can meet local artisans and watch them crafting pottery and masks from clay and bamboo, skills passed down through generations.

Majuli Island - Today is yours to explore Majuli at your own pace. You might wander through its peaceful villages, cycle along quiet lanes, or visit some of the island’s fascinating Vaishnava monasteries, known for their unique traditions of dance, music and storytelling.

Mon in Nagaland - Take the ferry back to Jorhat, then drive for around five hours to Mon in the neighbouring state of Nagaland. This is the land of the Konyak tribe, once renowned as tattooed head-hunters. On arrival, settle into your simple accommodation, then take a stroll through town to start absorbing the rhythms of daily life and the distinctive culture of this remote region.

Around Mon - With a packed lunch, set off on the two-hour drive to Longwa, a remote village where tribal traditions have changed little over the centuries. As you walk through its narrow lanes, you might see smoke curling from wood-fired kitchens, hear the steady rhythm of weaving looms, and notice the intricate tattoos worn by elders – each marking a story from their past. Longwa is also home to the local king, whose wooden home famously straddles the border between India and Myanmar, symbolising his authority over villages in both countries.

Dibrugarh, Tea Country of Assam - It’s roughly a five-hour drive to Dibrugarh, where you’ll check in to the charming Mancotta Chang Bungalow, a former tea planter’s house now operating as a heritage hotel. From here, you can explore the surrounding tea gardens, stroll into town to browse the bustling markets, and sample some authentic Assamese cuisine. A visit to Haaj-Paar, a local weaving centre where women craft traditional textiles, is also highly recommended.

Dibrugarh - Spend the day exploring Dibrugarh at your own pace. For those who wish, excursions can be arranged to nearby highlights, such as the striking Temple of Bells or Namphake, a traditional Buddhist village where you can experience local customs and way of life.
Fly to Delhi & Fly Home - After breakfast, check out of your hotel and enjoy a scenic drive to the airport for your flight to Delhi, where you’ll connect with your onward journey home.
